fields.Description/Abstract: <p><span>Offshore wind development is in its nascent stages in the United States. Recent research indicates that the visual impacts of offshore <a href="https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/wind-turbine" title="Learn more about wind farms from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages">wind farms</a> are viewed negatively by the general population. This North Carolina application is the first US-focused discrete choice experiment that explicitly asks respondents to consider the positive local and global benefits from offshore wind development, such as job creation and <a href="https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/greenhouse-gas-emission" title="Learn more about greenhouse gas emission from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages">greenhouse gas emission</a> reductions, simultaneously with their visual impacts. We find significant <a href="https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/social-sciences/willingness-to-pay" title="Learn more about willingness to pay from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages">willingness to pay</a> (WTP) for reducing the visual impacts of offshore <a href="https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/wind-turbine" title="Learn more about wind farms from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages">wind farms</a>, and that the extent of disamenity varies in the population and with placement along developed tourist towns (as much as $783/year for three years) or preserved coastlines (as much as $451/year for three years). We also find that some preference classes value projects that create permanent jobs and reduce </span><a href="https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/carbon-dioxide-emission" title="Learn more about carbon emissions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages">carbon emissions</a><span>. We use our estimates of preferences for the positive and negative attributes to explore specific wind farm configurations and locations that could achieve positive consensus in a heterogenous population.</span></p>
